Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Ecological Context for Bioavailable Phosphorus in Sub-Boreal Forest Soils of Northern Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fire is an important driver of ecosystem processes yet very little is known about its effects on phosphorus (P), which is an essential nutrient for plant and animal life and limited in northern Japanese soils. Soil microbes and fauna, such as earthworms, provide an essential function in forest ecosystems by digesting organic matter to make P and other nutrients available for plants that otherwise exist in unavailable forms. At the same time, plants chemically alter their immediate root zones to enhance the availability and uptake of P from soils. The common measurement of soil P does not account for the variety of root-zone acquisition techniques and very little is known about earthworm alteration of soil P availability. This research project will measure soil P in contrasting soil types of northern Japan with an advanced method that mimics the variety of plant P acquisition techniques. In a laboratory experiment, we will combine soils with a common earthworm species and charcoal from wildfires in order to provide a context for biological activity and forest disturbance that is likely to alter soil P availability. The project will be conducted in the extensively studied Teshio Experimental Forest located in northern Hokkaido, Japan, in collaboration with Assistant Professor Dr. Kobayashi Makoto and Associate Professor Dr. Kentaro Takagi of Hokkaido University. The Teshio Experimental Forest is an ideal field research center that provides 22,550 hectares of undisturbed sub-boreal forests.

The unique forests of northern Japan represent a transition from the far northern, cold boreal forests to warmer, biologically diverse temperate forests. The sub-boreal forests of northern Japan can provide an example for the future forests in the boreal zone. Previous research conducted in the Teshio Experimental Forest provides a valuable baseline for plant-soil interactions, nutrient cycling, forest ecology, and fire history. The area also contains a unique compilation of soil types and that can be extrapolated to different regions and environmental conditions. Total soil P concentrations are low in both serpentine and sedimentary soils of northern Japan; thus, rapid uptake by plants and soil microbes is likely. Research conducted by Dr. Makoto suggests that both plants and microbes employ specialized mechanisms to acquire P in the presence of charcoal, a ubiquitous residue of wildfires. Furthermore, the high earthworm density and activity in northern Japan forest soils may induce processes that have the capacity to directly or indirectly alleviate soil P limitations. With this collaboration, we will build on previous research from Hokkaido University to clarify the understanding of plant-soil and plant-soil fauna interactions in the availability of P in forest ecosystems.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Forest fire disturbances and earthworm activity are an important drivers of ecosystem processes, yet very little is known about the effects on soil phosphorus (P) pools and cycling. This essential nutrient for plant and animal life is limited in occurrence and solubility in forest soils and where volcanic ash is present, such as soils of northern Japan. Soil earthworms provide an essential function in forest ecosystems by digesting organic matter to make P and other nutrients available for plants. At the same time, plants chemically alter the soil that is directly in contact with plant roots to enhance the availability and uptake of P. The common measurement of soil P does not account for the variety of root-zone acquisition techniques.

The purpose of this study was to assess the combined effects of charcoal and earthworms in contrasting soil types of northern Japan using a novel biologically based P (BBP) extraction method, which mimics a variety of plant P acquisition strategies. We combined soils developed on serpentine and sedimentary parent materials with native earthworms and bamboo charcoal in a fully-factorial microcosm incubation experiment for four weeks. Soils were extracted in parallel after the incubation with the four BBP method solutions: CaCl2 (measures soluble P), citric acid (chelate extractable P), phosphatase (enzyme extractable organic P), and HCl (mineral occluded P). The treatment effects were highest in sedimentary soil types and where charcoal and earthworms were both present. Soils developed on serpentine parent material may have limited BBP due to P adsorption by metals, especially Mn. Phosphorus measured by HCl-extraction, representing recalcitrant inorganic P, yielded the highest BBP in treatments that combined charcoal and earthworms. Our findings suggest that charcoal content and earthworm activity may help stimulate P cycling via biological acquisition in northern Japanese forests.

Forest soils occupy diverse environments that are constantly altered by biotic and abiotic conditions such as precipitation, temperature, disturbances, biological organisms, and human activity. While dynamic, forest soils also fulfill essential functions by facilitating nutrient cycling, decomposition, biomass production, and delivering clean air and water. These processes and interactions with the environment are poorly understood. Our research findings provide evidence that (1) soil P bioavailability is increased by the interactive effects of charcoal deposited by wildfires and earthworm activity, and (2) that these effects are influenced by different soil types. The availability of this essential nutrient, phosphorus, is dependent on the biotic and abiotic context of the soil environment.

This award was responsible for the international exchange of scientific ideas and provided a valuable learning experience for both the host institution and the award recipient. Our research team completed the research project at the host university in Japan and presented results at the Soil Science Society of America national meeting in Phoenix, Arizona in November of 2016. We are also preparing a manuscript for a peer-review publication. Our research findings provide a minor advance in soil ecology and biogeochemistry, but a concept that our research team will utilize to build a greater understanding of nature with future research projects.
